Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing HF10 Therapy and Traditional SCS for Chronic Pain

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants with chronic intractable pain (VAS ≥5.0/10.0 cm) were randomised 1:1

Participants.evidence: Participants with chronic intractable pain (VAS ≥5.0/10.0 cm) were randomised 1:1 to receive HF10 therapy or traditional SCS.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised 1:1 to receive HF10 therapy or traditional SCS.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the long-term efficacy of 10-kHz high-frequency (HF10) spinal cord stimulation (SCS) compared to traditional low-frequency SCS in treating chronic back and leg pain.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the responder rate, defined as ≥50% reduction in back pain at 3 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was stratified by sex and primary pain area, with allocation concealment via centrally administered blocks.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not feasible due to therapy differences.

Number_Randomised.evidence: From June to December 2012, 198 participants were randomised (101 HF10, 97 traditional SCS).

Number_Analysed.evidence: 198 participants were randomised (101 HF10, 97 traditional SCS).

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 24 months, 76.5% of HF10 and 49.3% of traditional SCS participants were responders for back pain (27.2% difference, 95% CI, 10.1%-41.8%; P < .001).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were similar between groups.
